Job.JobTitle: Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach at Anthony Califano is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Anthony Califano, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Anthony Califano operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Anthony Califano with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Coach - GOHS Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach role at Anthony Califano.

Job.JobTitle: Coach - GOHS Assistant Football Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - GOHS Assistant Football Coach position at Anthony Califano is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Coach - GOHS Assistant Football Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Anthony Califano, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Coach - GOHS Assistant Football Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Coach - GOHS Assistant Football Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Coach - GOHS Assistant Football Coach role at Anthony Califano is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Trainer
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Trainer position at ABC Unified School District High Schools is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Athletic Trainer works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Athletic Trainer at ABC Unified School District High Schools sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At ABC Unified School District High Schools, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Athletic Trainer encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Athletic Trainer is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Athletic Trainer position at ABC Unified School District High Schools is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Athletic Coach at Compton Unified School District is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Athletic Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Compton Unified School District, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Athletic Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Athletic Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. The coach is expected to represent Compton Unified School District with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At University of San Diego, the Assistant Men's & Women's Cross Country Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Assistant Men's & Women's Cross Country Coach at University of San Diego is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Position Summary: Under the lead work direction of the Head Athletic Trainer, and the general supervision of the Athletic Director, the Athletic Trainer I follows established guidelines and procedures in providing the full range of clinical athletic training functions for student-athletes during training and competition, in accordance with the National Collegiate Athletics Association (NCAA) and National Athletic Trainers Association (NATA) guidelines. The Athletic Trainer I also provides injury prevention, evaluation, and rehabilitation for athletic injuries and assists in coverage of athletic practices and contests, including evening and weekend assignments and travel with teams.
Key Responsibilities: 40% - Injury Treatment/Rehabilitation a. Prevent, recognize, and assess athletic injuries. b. Inform coaching staff and other health professionals on the status of injuries and treatment plans. c. Implement rehabilitation programs for athletic injuries using appropriate therapeutic modalities and treatments. d. Monitor rehabilitation plans and progress. e. Assist with and assign student-athletes for therapy as needed. f. Consult with more senior Athletic Trainers, physicians, and other health care staff on injuries and treatment plans and coordinate with coaching staff. g. Maintain equipment and cleanliness of the athletic training and rehabilitation facilities.
20% - Evaluation/Prevention/Conditioning of Injuries a. Regularly evaluate the physical condition of student athletes. Advise students on how to prevent injuries and maintain their physical condition. Counsel athletes and staff regarding conditioning, athletic training, and rehabilitation. Assist in designing conditioning programs to prevent injuries.
15% - Home & Away Game & Practice Health Care a. Attend practices and athletic events to provide medical emergency coverage to student athletes. Travel with sports teams to away games as needed.
10% - Administrative Recordkeeping a. Maintain updated files and accurate medical records of the following: athletic injuries, medical insurance, medical history, injury referrals, conditioning programs, schedules, and other necessary data.
10% - Home & Away Game & Practice Health Care a. Coordinate clinical and physical appointments between athlete and SHC or outside referral. Inform coaching staff and other healthcare professionals regarding injury status and treatment plans. Daily control of infection and sanitation of the training room by cleaning and disinfecting all equipment, floors, and tables.
5% - Other Duties as Assigned
Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities Associated with this Position Include: General Knowledge of: Principles and practices of athletic training including conditioning, injury prevention, injury assessment and rehabilitation. Full range of therapeutic modalities and their practical use and physiological basis. Other therapeutic preventions and treatments such as taping, bracing, and therapeutic massage techniques. Effective use of rehabilitation and exercise equipment. Rules, regulations, and guidelines established by the campuses' governing national collegiate athletic associations pertaining to student-athletes, their training, sports medicine care, and health and safety. Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) standards for handling blood borne pathogens. Maintaining medical records, including Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) standards. Following insurance procedures.
Skills: Strong interpersonal and communications skills to develop effective working relationships with athletes and serve as a liaison among athletes, coaching staff, parents, physicians and other health professionals.
Ability to: Determine the appropriate referrals for athletes to other health care professionals. Recognize life threatening situations and administer the appropriate emergency aid. Use a computer to perform medical, insurance and other record keeping functions. Work in an environment with competing priorities. Communicate with coaches and student-athletes regarding injuries and rehabilitation plans. Work outside under varied weather conditions. Ability to communicate effectively with a diverse population, both verbally and in writing.
Minimum Qualifications: 1. Possess and maintain Board of Certification (BOC) certification for Athletic Trainer. 2. Possess and maintain valid state-issued driver's license with a clean driving record. 3. Current CPR/AED certification under the guidelines of the NATABOC
Preferred Qualifications: 1. Experience performing athletic training duties in a collegiate setting. 2. Masters degree in Athletic Training.

What it Means to Work Here When you join the team at SFUSD, you can expect to be part of an inclusive, innovative curriculum and community where all students arenormalization of courageous leaders. This is a place where you can make a lasting impact on the students and families of San Francisco, and where you’ll get the support you need to do work that’s transforming education.
About the Athletics Department: The SFUSD Athletics Department is a comprehensive K-12 program that includes physical education, intramural sports, and interscholastic athletics. The department serves as a resource for schools, coaches, and families, providing information and support on a wide range of topics related to athletics. The department also works to promote sportsmanship and fair play, and to ensure that all students have the opportunity to participate in athletics regardless of their ability or background.
Who We Want We want someone who is passionate about athletics and committed to providing a positive experience for all students. The ideal candidate will be a strong leader with excellent communication and organizational skills. They will also be able to work effectively with a wide range of people, including students, coaches, parents, and school staff.
Essential Duties: • Oversees the daily operation of assigned program to ensure that the goals and objectives of the program are met. • Assists in developing and recommending program goals, objectives, policies and procedures, including budgetary recommendations to the Commissioner; implements approved policies and procedures for assigned programs to ensure effective and efficient program operations. • Perform all functions involving website management, communications, and marketing of assigned regular season and championship events through multiple social media platforms (i.e. website, Twitter, Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat, YouTube) to maximize exposure and drive attendance. • Assist Commissioner with the supervision and management of personnel to include: holding staff accountable towards meeting division short and long-term goals; providing professional development with district staff, including the legal department, on harassment, crisis response, behavioral threat assessment, sexual abuse, and coordinated care approaches. • Build a deep understanding of the Division’s budget and the District’s budget development process to lead preparation of a proposed annual budget for the SFUSD Athletics Office partnering with the Business Services Department as needed. • Develop communication plans, produce weekly online newsletters, oversee production of programs, support AAA schools with promotional activities, maintain historical records and mandated statistics for assigned programs. • Create infrastructure for operational systems and structures for resource management, professional development and training resources, tracking tools and communication templates to strengthen capacity and coordination across Division and strengthen the capacity of all employees to give and receive feedback. • Coordinates programs and policies set by the Board of Manager and CIF; serves as a District liaison to organizations. • Serves as advisor to principals and their staff, community members, and public agencies in the initiation, development, interpretation, and evaluation of the athletics program as an integral part of the total educational program. • Identify and implement program and operational improvements that ensure the highest level of customer service for all employees. • Maintain relationships with district wide partners including the Instructional LEAD department and, Special Education Department, and others to assist with facilitating our district wide athletic programs. Develop emergency and crisis consultation systems for Athletics in partnership with the department and Divisional Leadership Teams. • Evaluates the facilities and environment of the athletics program from an educational viewpoint, to ensure proper function, safety, and sanitary conditions. • Responsible for implementing all updated athletic-specific COVID 19 compliance, in conjunction with California Department of Public Health and San Francisco Department of Public Health guidance, as well as District policy. Minimum Qualifications • Bachelor's degree (B.A./B.S.) from an accredited college or university; preferably in sports management, accounting, communications, and/or law • Two (2) years of professional-level athletic administration experience; preferably in a high school or collegiate athletic conference or large K-12 public urban school district Substitution: Education requirement may be substituted for additional experience on a year-for-year basis What We Offer SFUSD offers a competitive salary of $110,580 - $151,049/annually commensurate with experience in a similar position. We offer a comprehensive benefits plan including dental and vision plans, a defined benefit pension plan, disability, life insurance, flexible spending account options and vacation time. We also offer an inclusive and equity-centered environment where we encourage staff to bring their whole selves to work. The Assistant Coach Pool (all sports) role at California State University - Sacramento emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Coach Pool (all sports) coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Coach Pool (all sports) must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at California State University - Sacramento.

The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.

The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the COACH: Boys Track & Field Head Coach | Foothill High School supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the COACH: Boys Track & Field Head Coach | Foothill High School may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Foothill High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Lisette Nunez, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Girls Lacrosse JV Coach - Mission Viejo Hills High School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Lisette Nunez, the Girls Lacrosse JV Coach - Mission Viejo Hills High School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Girls Lacrosse JV Coach - Mission Viejo Hills High School at Lisette Nunez is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Madison Elementary (2025-2026 School Year) (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field)
Job.JobDescription:
The Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Madison Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) at Madison Elementary is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Madison Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Madison Elementary, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Madison Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Madison Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Madison Elementary operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Madison Elementary with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Madison Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Madison Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) role at Madison Elementary.

Job.JobTitle: Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary (2025-2026 School Year) (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field)
Job.JobDescription:
The Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) position at Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary, the Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Spring Sports Opportunities - Coach - Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary (Baseball, Softball, Track & Field) at Jaswant Singh Khalsa Elementary is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Athletic Trainer
Job.JobDescription:
Department Description: As part of the University of San Diego, a Roman Catholic University, the Department of Intercollegiate Athletics is committed to advancing academic and athletic excellence and enhancing students' lives while promoting the University of San Diego.
University Description: The University of San Diego, an engaged and contemporary<y_bin_358>Catholic institution, was founded by the Diocese of San Diego and the Society of the Sacred Heart in 1949. Governed by an independent board of trustees since 1972, USD remains committed to a liberal arts education grounded in the Catholic intellectual tradition and the pursuit of truth, goodness and beauty. Inspired by this centuries old tradition of Catholic higher education, the University welcomes people of all faith traditions and any, or no, religious background. The future success of USD relies on the contributions of those who seek to foster the development of engaged global citizens and an earnest confrontation of humanity’s urgent challenges.
Duties and Responsibilities: The Assistant Athletic Trainer is responsible for all aspects of healthcare in the athletic environment. This includes prevention of athletic injuries; recognition and evaluation of injuries; management, treatment, and disposition of athletic injuries; rehabilitation of athletic injuries; organization and administration; and education and counseling of athletes, as outlined by the National Athletic Trainers Association (NATA). This position must maintain appropriate certifications and Continuing Education Units (CEUs) as required in the field.
Prevention:
Assist with scheduling and organizing team pre-participation physicals and review of athletes' health history. Assist team physician(s). Oversee selection of proper fitting plus maintenance of protective equipment, including the use of adhesive tape, bandages, and orthoses. Reduce and control environmental hazards, thereby creating a safe environment. Practice Universal Precautions when exposed to bodily fluids.
Detailed Description: Recognition and Evaluation:
Assess athletes' health status through comprehensive injury evaluations. Refer to team physician(s) and/or other medical specialists as needed. Provide emergency care and first aid as needed. Implement athletic training staff emergency care procedures as needed. Facilitate transportation logistics to expedite emergency care as needed. Maintain cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and AED certification. Time permitting, provide first aid and injury referral of non-intercollegiate and club sport participants.
Rehabilitation:
Under supervision of the team physician, administer therapeutic modalities. Design and implement injury rehabilitation programs. Implement a sport-specific and injury-specific “return to play” plan. Design and fit specific orthopedic devices. Apply therapeutic and protective bandaging and wrapping for practices and contests.
Organization and Administration:
Assist in administering the University Athletic Injury insurance policy and claims processing. Coordinate primary and University insurance information for medical providers. Assist in annually providing students and parents/guardians with written information regarding the University Athletic Injury policy. Assist in annually acquiring and maintaining primary insurance information for individual athletes. Maintain accurate health, injury, treatment, rehabilitation and physician referrals for individual athletes. Maintain daily treatment records and rehabilitation progress notes. Protect the athlete's privacy. Supervise and teach athletic training students. Participate in the education of student athletic trainers. Maintain athletic training room facilities in a safe and sanitary condition. Apply University and Athletic Department policies and regulations in regard to the use/abuse of alcohol and drugs. Assist with NCAA and/or institutional drug testing.
Additional Responsibilities:
This position will provide athletic training services to all intercollegiate sports as assigned, including team travel. This position will also oversee and supervise the graduate assistant athletic trainer assigned to the sports of men's and women's cross country, indoor and outdoor track. Communicate effectively with athletes, coaches, team physicians, Athletic Department staff, and administrators. Maintain professional memberships, including NATA and CPR. Maintain NATA certification through continuing education. Attend Athletic Department and Sports Medicine staff meetings. All other duties as assigned by the Assistant Athletic Director for Sports Medicine.
Job Requirements: Minimum Qualifications:
Bachelor's Degree NATA Certification First Aid, CPR and AED Certification Minimum of one-year experience Ability to provide evening and weekend coverage Valid Driver’s License
Performance Expectations - Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
Excellent communication and interpersonal skills. Ability to work effectively and cooperatively with student-athletes, coaches, administrators and physicians. A commitment to the welfare and development of student-athletes. Ability to handle confidential information with tact and discretion. Knowledge of NCAA rules and regulations. A commitment to the mission and values of the University of San Diego.
Special Conditions of Employment: Effective June 1, 2023, based on CDC guidance, the University strongly encourages all campus members to stay up to date with Influenza and COVID-19 vaccination recommendations. For more regarding information USD's COVID-19 protocols, please visit sandiego.edu/onward.
The University of San Diego is requiring all employees to follow our Covid-19 vaccine requirement process. https://www.sandiego.edu/onward/
Background check: Successful completion of a pre-employment background check.
Degree Verification Requirement: Before contact-offer, successful candidates must submit documentation of higher education degree(s) verification (i.e., official transcript(s) or original diploma(s)). If the default original diploma(s) is not available, a copy of the original diploma(s) sealed together with the original transcript(s) is acceptable. Click here for USD Degree Verification Requirement Guidelines.
Tools and Equipment Used: Knowledge of and experience with operation of all therapeutic modalities, rehabilitation equipment, first aid equipment, and office equipment (e.g., computer, fax, copy machine, telephone).
Posting Salary: $5,720 - $5,900 per month; Excellent Benefits
The University of San Diego offers a very competitive benefits package including;
Medical, dental, vision, a retirement contribution given to you by the University, and access to San Diego’s premiere campus recreation facility. Appreciated by employees, the University also offers substantial tuition remission for employees, spouses and dependents. At the University of San Diego, our culture is strongly influenced by our Catholic tradition, we value the dignity of every individual, embrace diversity, and highlight a commitment to service.
Special Application Instructions: Resume and Cover Letter Required Click Apply Now to complete our online application. In addition, please upload a cover letter and resume to your application profile for the hiring managers’ review. If you have any questions or difficulties please contact the Employment Services Team at 619-260-6806, or email us at jobs@sandiego.edu
Additional Details: 40 Hours per week
Closing date: Open until filled
Note: External job postings will be up for at least five days. After that time, applications will be reviewed by the hiring manager/committee throughout the screening process. An offer may be made to an applicant at any time during the hiring process.
The University of San Diego is an equal opportunity employer committed to diversity and inclusion and is especially interested in candidates who can contribute to the diversity and excellence of the academic community. The University of San Diego is a smoking and tobacco-free campus. For more information, visit www.sandiego.edu/smokefree. Sponsorship is not available for this position.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Assistant
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Assistant position at San Diego City Colleges is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Athletic Assistant is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At San Diego City Colleges, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Athletic Assistant encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Athletic Assistant also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Athletic Assistant role at San Diego City Colleges is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boy's Basketball Coach position at Clarksville-Mongomery County provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant Boy's Basketball Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Clarksville-Mongomery County, the Assistant Boy's Basketball Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant Boy's Basketball Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant Boy's Basketball Coach at Clarksville-Mongomery County is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Maintains current knowledge of the governing policies, rules, regulations, procedures and eligibility requirement of the District and appropriate sports athletic association. Establishes goals and objectives for the sport season in accordance with established District goals and objectives. Conducts appropriate meetings with students to promote the sport, explain requirements, issue and retrieve necessary forms for insurance, eligibility, physical exams, and parental permission, and discuss athletic health care, development, and training, care of injuries and sportsmanship, and conduct. Scheduling, planning, and content organization of fall and spring practices. Scheduling, planning, and content organization of fall and spring strength training and conditioning. Supervision of students and assistant coaches at practices and contests. Coordinates the scheduling of activities, use of facilities, eligibility lists, transportation of student-athletes, and game management with appropriate building personnel and in accordance with building athletic policy and codes. Provides for safety and welfare of participants; maintains injury records and other athletic records as necessary. Issues and retrieves athletic equipment; arranges for cleaning, repair, storage, and inventory; holds athletes responsible for care and return of District-owned equipment. Expends approved budget in conformance with District fiscal procedures; recommends budget needs; requisitions supplies and equipment within budget constraints. Update records of the team and individual records and accomplishments; arrange for school athletic awards. Promotes the total sports program with the student body, administration, teaching staff, and the public; provides pertinent and timely game schedules and results to the news media. Evaluates the sports program and provides reports and recommendations to the appropriate administration for management decision-making purposes. Knowledge of and compliance with the rules and regulations as required by the TSSAA. Knowledge of and compliance with NCAA recruiting rules and regulations. Reports immediately, as required by law, to the appropriate agency(ies) and the principal or other persons designated by the school system, incidents of actual or suspected child abuse, actual or suspected child sexual abuse. Reports immediately, as required by law or school policy, to the appropriate agency(ies) and/or the principal or other persons designated by the school system, incidents involving unlawful student possession of weapons or drugs or fighting on school property. Responds in a prompt and professional manner to inquiries from a variety of sources (e.g. teachers, students, parents, administrators, boosters, etc.). The Volunteer Asst. Ladies Soccer Coach (Southside Combined) role at Washington County is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Volunteer Asst. Ladies Soccer Coach (Southside Combined) is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Washington County are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Volunteer Asst. Ladies Soccer Coach (Southside Combined) listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.

Ladies Soccer Coach (Southside Combined) follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Washington County, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Volunteer Asst. Ladies Soccer Coach (Southside Combined) at Washington County, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Track Coach (Non-paid position) at David Crockett High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Assistant Track Coach (Non-paid position) plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at David Crockett High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Assistant Track Coach (Non-paid position) expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Assistant Track Coach (Non-paid position) supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Assistant Track Coach (Non-paid position) may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at David Crockett High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Head Coach - Football
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach - Football role at Kentridge High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Coach - Football is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Kentridge High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Head Coach - Football listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Coach - Football encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Coach - Football follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Kentridge High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Coach - Football at Kentridge High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: HEAD COACH - BASEBALL

The HEAD COACH - BASEBALL at Rogers High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the HEAD COACH - BASEBALL are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Rogers High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The HEAD COACH - BASEBALL recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the HEAD COACH - BASEBALL collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The HEAD COACH - BASEBALL maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Rogers High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Football - Assistant Coach - Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
POSITION SUMMARY: Middle school assistant coaches oversee the growth and development of student athletes by focusing on fundamental skills instruction with an emphasis on whole child development to include expectations for academic and athletic excellence, leadership skills, and positive social relationships.
Per WIAA requirements, you must be at least 19 years of age to apply for any assistant coaching positions and 21 years of age to apply for any head coaching positions.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES include the following. This list is meant to be representative, not exhaustive. Some incumbents may not perform all the duties listed while in other cases related duties may also be assigned. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions: General 1. Professional Development and Leadership. The assistant coach will keep abreast of knowledge and techniques associated with his/her sport by staying current with sport-specific literature and attending clinics and workshops. 2. Responsibility for Rules and Regulations. The assistant coach will study the rules and regulations associated with his/her sport. The assistant coach will read and understand the rules and regulations of the Washington Interscholastic Activities Association (WIAA), Federal Way Public Schools, and the league in which his/her team competes. 3. Program Promotion. The assistant coach will promote his/her sport within the school and encourage students to participate. 4. Program Organization. The assistant coach is expected to hold practice on a daily basis. Absence from practice should be for illness and/or an emergency situation only and must be cleared in advance by the building athletic director. The head coach is not authorized to excuse an assistant from practice. 5. Standard of Care. The assistant coach is expected to model safety training relative to his/her sport as demonstrated and directed by the head coach. The assistant coach is expected to have a working knowledge of basic athletic training skills and procedures. He/she should be able to perform basic taping and first aid functions. 6. Professionalism. The assistant coach is expected to exercise good judgment and project positive coaching behaviors. The assistant coach is expected to assume a major role in the molding of student athletes in his/her program and the school/community at large. The assistant coach is expected to teach and develop basic skills fundamentals, leadership characteristics, and cooperative, team-oriented behavior. His/her approach is expected to be even keel, calm, and positive. He/she is expected to be contemplative and fair-minded. 7. Sportsmanship and Ethics. The assistant coach is expected to serve as an example of sportsmanship and humility at all times. When faced with obstacles or losses, he/she is expected to handle each instance with grace, dignity, and pride. The assistant coach must model and insist upon ethical behavior and good citizenship at all times. Administrative 1. Supervision. The assistant coach is responsible for participants in his/her program from the time they report until the time they leave. 2. Presentation of Rules/Regulations. The Assistant coach thoroughly understands and reinforces eligibility requirements, participation rules, and the District Eligibility Code as demonstrated and directed by the head coach. 3. Attention to Eligibility Rules. The Assistant Coach ensures that each program participant has completed the eligibility process before taking part in any form of practice activity. 4. Accident/Injury Procedure. The assistant coach is expected to call 911 without hesitation for serious and/or difficult to assess injuries. The assistant coach is expected to fill out and submit an Accident Report Form to the building athletic director within 24 hours of a student or staff member being injured. Emergency situations are to be immediately reported to the building athletic director and director of athletics. 5. Meeting Attendance. The assistant coach is expected to attend building, district, and league meetings. 6. Responsibility for Playing Facility and Equipment. The assistant coach immediately reports safety concerns to the head coach and assumes responsibility for the care of equipment and facilities used in the program. 7. Violations and Ejections Procedure. The assistant coach is expected to report a violation and/or ejection to the head coach, building athletic director, and director of athletics immediately following the contest where the infraction occurred. 8. Coach Evaluation Process. The assistant coach is expected to attend an evaluation meeting with the building athletic director following the season. 9. Assistant Coach as Program Leader. The assistant coach is expected to meet with the head coach in advance of the season to develop program goals and discuss a plan to ensure consistent instruction of fundamental skills, systems, and strategies. Financial and Equipment 1. Responsibility for Program Equipment, Supplies, and Inventory. The assistant coach is responsible for his/her program’s equipment and supplies and is expected to account for all program-related items checked out to him/her at the start of the season. 2. Program Purchases. The assistant coach is expected to request essential program needs through the head coach and is not to purchase program items with personal funds. 3. Fundraising Activities. The assistant coach is expected to work through the head coach to discuss potential fundraising activities and is not to raise or handle funds without advance approval from the building athletic director. OTHER RESPONSIBILITIES: Performs other related duties as assigned for the purpose of ensuring the efficient and effective functioning of the work unit and supporting student learning objectives. The preceding list of responsibilities is not exhaustive and may be supplemented as necessary. REQUIRED QUALIFICATIONS: Education and Experience High school diploma or equivalent One year of sport-specific playing and/or coaching experience in a secondary and/or post-secondary athletics program and/or related club coaching experience. Proven training and experience in the presentation of drills, safety factors, and proper application of skills. ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS: Work scheduled hours on a consistent basis PREFERRED QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years of paid middle school and/or post-secondary sport-specific coaching experience and/or related club coaching experience. Completion of the National Federation Coaching Fundamentals Course to include passing the test. CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT: 21 years of age or older
Job.Experience: One year of sport-specific playing and/or coaching experience in a secondary and/or post-secondary athletics program and/or related club coaching experience.

Job.JobDescription: QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspect such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Plainwell Community Schools' Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation by the entire staff of the sports program. 2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations; implements same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance. STAFF RESPONSIBILITIES: 4. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by staff. Designs conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program. 5. Trains and informs staff, encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy. 6. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation and, at season's end, analyzes staff effectiveness and evaluates all assistants. 7. Maintains discipline, adjusts grievances and works to increase morale and cooperation. 8. Performs such other duties which may be assigned by the athletic director/principal. ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES: 9. Assists the athletic director in scheduling, providing transportation and requirements for tournament and special sport events. 10. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees. 11. Provides documentation to fulfill state and system requirements concerning physical examinations, parental consent and eligibility. 12. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. 13. Advises the athletic director and recommends policy, method or procedural changes. STUDENT RESPONSIBILITIES: 14. Serves as a mentor to each athlete to promote the development and demonstration in student athletes the character traits of trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 15. Gives constant attention to a student athlete's grades and conduct. 16. By his/her presence at all practices games and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance and safeguards for each participant.

Job.JobTitle: Coach - Girls Assistant Varsity Basketball(REPOST)
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Girls Assistant Varsity Basketball(REPOST) at Upland High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Coach - Girls Assistant Varsity Basketball(REPOST) plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Upland High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Coach - Girls Assistant Varsity Basketball(REPOST) expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Coach - Girls Assistant Varsity Basketball(REPOST) supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Coach - Girls Assistant Varsity Basketball(REPOST) may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Upland High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: ASSISTANT COACH - FOOTBALL - Monta Vista High School, 2026-2027 School Year
Job.JobDescription:
The ASSISTANT COACH - FOOTBALL - Monta Vista High School, 2026-2027 School Year position at Monta Vista High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the ASSISTANT COACH - FOOTBALL - Monta Vista High School, 2026-2027 School Year prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Monta Vista High School, the ASSISTANT COACH - FOOTBALL - Monta Vista High School, 2026-2027 School Year works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The ASSISTANT COACH - FOOTBALL - Monta Vista High School, 2026-2027 School Year encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the ASSISTANT COACH - FOOTBALL - Monta Vista High School, 2026-2027 School Year at Monta Vista High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: SPORTS COACH JOB NO. 1158
Job.JobDescription:
The SPORTS COACH JOB NO. 1158 role at Moises Benito is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the SPORTS COACH JOB NO. 1158 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Moises Benito are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The SPORTS COACH JOB NO. 1158 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the SPORTS COACH JOB NO. 1158 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The SPORTS COACH JOB NO. 1158 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Moises Benito, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the SPORTS COACH JOB NO. 1158 at Moises Benito, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
