Job.JobTitle: Coach (Assistant)-Track & Field Varsity Girls- Novato High School Spring 2025-2026
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach (Assistant)-Track & Field Varsity Girls- Novato High School Spring 2025 position at Novato Unified School District provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Coach (Assistant)-Track & Field Varsity Girls- Novato High School Spring 2025 prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Novato Unified School District, the Coach (Assistant)-Track & Field Varsity Girls- Novato High School Spring 2025 works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Coach (Assistant)-Track & Field Varsity Girls- Novato High School Spring 2025 encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Coach (Assistant)-Track & Field Varsity Girls- Novato High School Spring 2025 at Novato Unified School District is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball at Glinda Medina is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Glinda Medina reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Glinda Medina. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year
Job.JobDescription:
The Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year position at Claudia Badillo is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Claudia Badillo, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year role at Claudia Badillo is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year (IN-HOUSE VACANCY - INTERNAL CANDIDATES ONLY)
Job.JobDescription:
The Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year (IN-HOUSE VACANCY - INTERNAL CANDIDATES ONLY) at Claudia Badillo is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year (IN-HOUSE VACANCY - INTERNAL CANDIDATES ONLY) is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Claudia Badillo, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year (IN-HOUSE VACANCY - INTERNAL CANDIDATES ONLY) helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year (IN-HOUSE VACANCY - INTERNAL CANDIDATES ONLY) works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Claudia Badillo operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Claudia Badillo with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year (IN-HOUSE VACANCY - INTERNAL CANDIDATES ONLY) reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Teacher Hourly - Intramural Sports Coach - 2025/2026 School Year (IN-HOUSE VACANCY - INTERNAL CANDIDATES ONLY) role at Claudia Badillo.

Job.JobTitle: Activities Coach - Girls Volleyball
Job.JobDescription:
The Activities Coach - Girls Volleyball role at Graham Middle School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Activities Coach - Girls Volleyball is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Graham Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Activities Coach - Girls Volleyball listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Activities Coach - Girls Volleyball encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Activities Coach - Girls Volleyball follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Graham Middle School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Activities Coach - Girls Volleyball at Graham Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: JV Girls Softball Assistant Coach - LAHS
Job.JobDescription:
The JV Girls Softball Assistant Coach - LAHS position at Michelle Noeth provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the JV Girls Softball Assistant Coach - LAHS prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Michelle Noeth, the JV Girls Softball Assistant Coach - LAHS works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The JV Girls Softball Assistant Coach - LAHS encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the JV Girls Softball Assistant Coach - LAHS at Michelle Noeth is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Head Varsity Girls' Water Polo Coach (Hanford High School)
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Varsity Girls' Water Polo Coach (Hanford High School) position at Beau Hill provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Head Varsity Girls' Water Polo Coach (Hanford High School) prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Beau Hill, the Head Varsity Girls' Water Polo Coach (Hanford High School) works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Head Varsity Girls' Water Polo Coach (Hanford High School) encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Head Varsity Girls' Water Polo Coach (Hanford High School) at Beau Hill is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27
Job.JobDescription:
The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 role at Mary Martinez is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Mary Martinez, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Mary Martinez, the DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 at Mary Martinez is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Softball Varsity Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Softball Varsity Coach role at Bassett Unified School District emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Softball Varsity Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Bassett Unified School District, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Softball Varsity Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Bassett Unified School District at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Softball Varsity Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Softball Varsity Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Softball Varsity Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Bassett Unified School District.

Job.JobTitle: Girls' Varsity Lacrosse Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Girls' Varsity Lacrosse Coach at Coronado Unified School District is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Girls' Varsity Lacrosse Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Coronado Unified School District, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Girls' Varsity Lacrosse Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Girls' Varsity Lacrosse Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Coronado Unified School District operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Coronado Unified School District with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Girls' Varsity Lacrosse Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Girls' Varsity Lacrosse Coach role at Coronado Unified School District.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Football Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Football Coach at Mountain Empire Unified School District is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Football Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Mountain Empire Unified School District, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Football Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Football Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Mountain Empire Unified School District operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Mountain Empire Unified School District with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Football Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Football Coach role at Mountain Empire Unified School District.

Each school is an inspiring and challenging environment where all staff and students value and celebrate diversity. Every student and family is unconditionally respected. The Wrestling Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Wrestling Coach at Jolene Towne is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Track Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Track Coach position at Kristie Pearson is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Track Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Track Coach at Kristie Pearson sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Kristie Pearson, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Track Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Track Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Track Coach position at Kristie Pearson is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Coach: Boys Basketball 25-26 School Year is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Vaca Pena Middle School, the Coach: Boys Basketball 25-26 School Year helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Coach: Boys Basketball 25-26 School Year may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Vaca Pena Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Coach: Boys Basketball 25-26 School Year follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Centinela Valley Union High School District Head Coach Job Description Job Summary: The Head Coach is responsible for various aspects of the program, such as recruiting within the school, scheduling opponents (in conjunction with the Athletic Director), training, and coaching team members. The Head Coach is required to abide by the CIF rules and regulations as well as the rules and regulations set by the Centinela Valley Union High School District and the athletic administration. Job Specifications: In order to be successful in this job, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skills and/or abilities required. Reasonable accommodation may be made to enable individuals with disabilities, who are otherwise qualified, to perform the essential functions. Essential Responsibilities: Manage and supervise athletic activities, contests, and practice sessions, to promote individual growth in athletic skills, teamwork, discipline, respect, and good sportsmanship. Prepare field/courts on Game Day and manage logistics for all lower level competitions Check and respond to Centinela Outlook email on a regular basis Use a variety of instructional techniques and media to meet the needs and improve the abilities of student-athletes. Coordinate the development and promotion of the specific Program. Work with other members of school staff to plan and put in place instructional goals and objectives to ensure the overall educational development of student athletes. Ensure all coaches work together toward a common goal within the program and provide unity within all levels of the program. Establish performance criteria for competition and evaluate students’ athletic abilities initially and on a regular basis. Develop a regular practice schedule and organize practice time to provide both individual and team development. Hold a preseason meeting with all student-athletes and parents before the first official game. Assess players’ skills and assign team positions. Determine game strategy based on the team’s capabilities. Monitor and enforce student eligibility criteria for extracurricular participation. Take all necessary precautions to protect student-athletes, equipment, and facilities, including protecting students from hazing/bullying. Maintain and secure all equipment and uniforms. Oversee the process of cleaning, repairing, and storing all athletic equipment. Communicating with the Athletic Director to ensure compliance with all pertinent CIF regulations, including eligibility forms, transfer forms, and grade reports. Instruct and advise students on NCAA regulations with regard to academic requirements for scholarships and recruiting practices. Assist student athletes with college recruitment. Assist the Athletic Director with the scheduling of games and coordinate arrangements. Act as a team representative and promote the sport by communicating with the news media, and other organizations. Participate in special activities to include senior night, banquets, award nights and pep assemblies. Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding athletic performance of their student. Coordinate with the ATC and established procedures in the event of an athlete’s injury. Represent the Centinela Valley Union High School District and program in a professional manner. Maintain nondiscriminatory practices in all activities. Attend staff development meetings, clinics, and other professional activities to improve coaching performance. Perform any other related duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or other appropriate administrator. Recommend, advocate, and attend all league, all area, and other award nominations. Additional Knowledge/Skills/Attributes/Certificates: Knowledge: Comprehensive knowledge of the game is paramount. Extensive knowledge of current coaching techniques and procedures. Knowledge of NFHS and CIF rules and regulations. Demonstrated ability to instruct and supervise student-athletes. Skills: The applicant must possess the ability to communicate in spoken and written word. Excellent organizational, communication, and interpersonal skills. The applicant must possess the ability to relate to students and to teach them on and off the field. The applicant must be willing to accept a high level of accountability. The applicant must possess the ability to assess players and coaches effectively. Attributes: The applicant should be professionally calm and motivationally intense. The applicant should be a progressive thinker but a believer in planning and preparation. Certificates: NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching or Sport Specific NFHS Concussion in Sports (every 2 years) NFHS Sudden Cardiac Arrest (every 2 years) NFHS Heat Illness Prevention (every 2 years) Valid CPR/First-Aid card Supervision Exercised: Assistant Coaches, Staff Supervision Received: Principal /Athletic Director This job description in no way states or implies that these are the only duties to be performed by this employee. CVUHSD reserves the right to update, revise or change this job description and related duties at any time.

Job.JobTitle: Varsity Track Head Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Track Head Coach role at Calipatria Unified emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Varsity Track Head Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Calipatria Unified, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Varsity Track Head Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Calipatria Unified at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Varsity Track Head Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Varsity Track Head Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Varsity Track Head Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Calipatria Unified.

Job.JobDescription:
The Any Core or CTE Teacher/Asst. Football and Asst. Basketball Coach at Lewisville Independent School Dist. is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Any Core or CTE Teacher/Asst. Football and Asst. Basketball Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Lewisville Independent School Dist. reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Any Core or CTE Teacher/Asst. Football and Asst. That means the Any Core or CTE Teacher/Asst. Football and Asst. Basketball Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Any Core or CTE Teacher/Asst. Football and Asst. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Lewisville Independent School Dist.. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Trainer Pool 2025-2026
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 position at Brownsville Independent School District is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 at Brownsville Independent School District sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Brownsville Independent School District, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 position at Brownsville Independent School District is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Athletic Trainer/ PE Teacher for Polk MS, Perry MS
Job.JobDescription:
Primary Purpose: Athletic Training Services: The management and provision of care of injuries to a physically active person as defined in the state practice act with the direction of a licensed physician. The term includes the rendering of emergency care, development of injury prevention programs and providing appropriate preventative and devices for the physically active person. The term also includes the assessment, management, treatment, rehabilitation and recondition of the physically active person whose conditions are within the professional preparation and education of a certified athletic trainer. The term also includes the use of modalities such as mechanical stimulation, heat, cold, light, air, water, electricity, sound, massage and the use of therapeutic exercises, reconditioning exercise and fitness programs.
Qualifications: Education/Certification: Bachelor’s degree, Masters preferred Licensed by the State of Texas as an Athletic Trainer, ATC preferred Valid State of Texas teaching certificate.
Major Responsibilities and Duties: Injury Prevention: Develop and implement comprehensive injury prevention programs tailored to individual athletes and teams. Educate athletes, coaches, and staff on injury prevention techniques, proper nutrition, and physical conditioning. Conduct pre-participation physical exams to identify potential risk factors for injury. Injury Evaluation and Treatment: Provide on-site emergency care and treatment for acute sports injuries. Evaluate athletic injuries, determining the nature and severity of the injury. Develop and implement appropriate treatment and rehabilitation plans, ensuring a safe return to activity. Rehabilitation: Design and monitor personalized rehabilitation programs for injured athletes. Utilize therapeutic modalities, exercises, and manual therapy techniques to aid in recovery. Collaborate with healthcare providers, including physicians and physical therapists, to ensure comprehensive care. Documentation and Reporting: Maintain accurate and up-to-date medical records for all athletes. Document injury evaluations, treatments, and rehabilitation progress in compliance with legal and ethical standards. Provide regular reports on injury trends and outcomes to the appropriate personnel. Collaboration and Communication: Work closely with coaches, team physicians, and other medical professionals to ensure the well-being of athletes. Communicate effectively with athletes and their families regarding injury status, treatment plans, and expected outcomes. Compliance and Professional Development: Stay current with industry best practices and continuing education requirements to maintain certification and licensure. Ensure compliance with all relevant regulations, standards, and guidelines, including those set by professional organizations and governing bodies.
In addition to being the Head Athletic Trainer: Maintain appropriate general treatment orders to be reviewed annually and approved by the team physician. Provide athletic training services for all home athletic contests and away varsity football games. If a conflict arises between an away varsity football game and a home contest, the varsity football event will supersede. Act as liaison between family physicians and specialists, the school district, athletes and their parents. Develop and maintain a budget for the athletic training program. Schedule and be present for pre-participation sports physicals. Provide the coaches and athletic director with a list of athletes medically eligible to compete under district and state rules and regulations. Assist the athletic director as requested.
In addition to being the Middle School Trainer: Teach sections of a content area such as PE or CTE. Coverage would be at two campuses; alternating days. Maintain appropriate general treatment orders to be reviewed annually and approved by the team physician. Job.JobDescription:
The High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 role at Birdville Independent School District is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Birdville Independent School District, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Birdville Independent School District, the High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the High School - Teacher / Coach Pool 2026 - 2027 at Birdville Independent School District is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment)
Job.JobDescription:
The HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) at Travis Bryan High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Travis Bryan High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The HS Coach, Head Volleyball (Open Teaching Assignment) maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Travis Bryan High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
Primary Purpose: The Strength and Conditioning Coordinator will oversee the design, implementation, and evaluation of strength and conditioning programs for all athletic teams at Temple High School and its feeder middle schools. This position is responsible for enhancing the physical and athletic performance of student-athletes while minimizing injury risk. The coordinator will work closely with coaches, athletic trainers, and the athletic director to ensure a comprehensive and cohesive approach to athlete development.
Education/Certification Bachelor’s degree in Kinesiology, Exercise Science, or a related field; Master’s degree preferred
Certification from a nationally recognized strength and conditioning organization (e.g., NSCA-CSCS, CSCCa-SCCC)
Current CPR/AED and First Aid certification
Experience 3+ years of experience as a strength and conditioning coach and/or athletic coach, preferably in a high school or collegiate setting
Experience in designing and implementing strength and conditioning programs for various sports
Knowledge of adolescent athletic development and injury prevention
Major Responsibilities and Duties: Instructional Management To promote improvement and provide effective instruction, the strength and conditioning coach: Designs and supervises weight training and conditioning programs for all boys’ and girls’ sports in Temple ISD for pre-season, in-season, and off-season. This includes setting up and taking down of all strength and conditioning equipment used daily. Works in cooperation with the middle school coaches to design and implement an effective strength and conditioning fundamental training model. Works in cooperation with athletic trainers in minimizing and rehabilitating injuries as well as the strengthening of injured athletes. Is responsible for the daily operation of the strength and conditioning facility as well as the coordination and scheduling of the facility before, after the school day, and throughout the year. Prepares well-organized, written strength & conditioning plans which utilize the coaching staff and team to its maximum potential. Plans, organizes, and directs summer strength & conditioning camps for both high school and middle school athletes. Communicates expected student behavior related to athletics and ensures student compliance. Organization Climate To foster a positive school or organization morale, the strength and conditioning coach: Maintains a clean, safe, and efficient weight facility. Maintains a positive working relationship with the TISD coaching staff. Organization Improvement To improve each school and sports program, the strength & conditioning coach: Establishes and monitors all rules and regulations that are to be followed by all users of TISD strength and conditioning facilities. Provides supervision and ensures the safety and security of athletes by closely monitoring conduct of athletes while using TISD strength and conditioning facilities. Communication and Community Relations To develop and promote positive communication and relations, the strength and conditioning coach: Creates, distributes, and maintains detailed, accurate and updated records for each high school athlete to track progress, develop work out schedules and assess effectiveness of programs. Provides a longitudinal report to each coach following the administration of performance assessments. Maintains all strength and conditioning facilities in the district (high school and middle schools), including but not limited to making recommendations for repairing or replacing equipment as needed. Maintains a current inventory of all strength and conditioning equipment within the district and submit to the director of athletics at the end of each school year. Works within proper framework of the athletic budget to recommend the purchase of equipment and supplies as deemed necessary and appropriate. Completes all tasks and assignments promptly and accurately, as assigned by the director of athletics. Professional Growth and Development Professional development for the strength and conditioning coach will include, but is not limited to the following: Teaching current techniques and strategies to coaches through demonstrations, videos, and various instructional platforms. Participating in national and state level organizations to stay abreast of latest research and best practices. Attending professional development opportunities and meetings related to designated subject areas. Reading, synthesizing, and disseminating research and information related to best practices from books, journals, list serves, Websites, and other media formats. Qualities of Effective Strength & Conditioning Coach The strength and conditioning coach exhibits the following qualities: Daily attendance and punctuality at work are essential functions of the coach. Complies with District policies, as well as state and federal laws and regulations. Demonstrates knowledge in strength training and continuous professional growth by keeping informed of modern trends, techniques, and strategies. Attends clinics and or conventions to maintain strength and conditioning license (NSCA/CSCS Certification). Follows professional, ethical, and legal parameters regarding use of drugs and therapeutic agents for treatment and rehabilitation of injured athletes. Acts as a positive role model for athletes and peers by dressing professionally for workouts, contests and personally modeling what is expected of the athletes and recognizing the importance his/her actions have on the developing young athlete. Demonstrates enthusiasm and dedication to the athletic department and student athletes. Always maintains expected weight room and office decorum. Demonstrates self-control and poise by maintaining self-control in all areas related to strength and conditioning coach responsibilities. Corrects unsafe conditions in work area that could cause an accident and inform Athletic Director of any conditions that are not correctable immediately. Performs all other duties as assigned by the Director of Athletics. Maintains confidentiality. Leadership Qualities Models a Commitment to Excellence by embracing a shared vision for the campus, utilizing innovative approaches to that align to the school vision, and influences others to achieve campus and district goals. Has the ability to Connect with All by building trust among peers, collaborates in a way that values varying perspectives, and communicates clearly with campus peers and administrators. Seeks opportunities to Invest in Growth by pursuing opportunities to learn, empowers teammates to grow and develop, and embraces reflective practices to encourage growth toward goal attainment. Supervisory Responsibilities: Supervise student-athletes/teams in training sessions, open weight-room session. Assist coaches in practice sessions. Equipment: Computer, printer, calculator, telephone, copier, fax machine, scanner, electronic devices, all athletic facility equipment, and other equipment applicable to the position. The RVHS Esports Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The RVHS Esports Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the RVHS Esports Coach position at Yuba City Unified School District is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: YCHS Cross Country Head Coach
Job.JobDescription:
QUALIFICATIONS:
1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program.
2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports)
3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport
and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field.
4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through
his/her instructions and actions.
REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in
conjunction with the high school principals
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of
high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the
athletic director and respective principal.
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training
necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same
time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially
acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of
accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills
through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's
image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable
responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is
taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good
mental health.
2. The position includes other unusual aspect such as extended time, risk injury
factor and due process predicaments.
3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to
function. In cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach
shall exercise common sense and good judgment.
DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Plainwell Community
Schools' Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation by the entire staff of the
sports program.
2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations; implements same consistently and
interprets them for staff.
3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through
proper channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance.
STAFF RESPONSIBILITIES:
4. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by staff. Designs
conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program.
5. Trains and informs staff, encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according
to local clinic policy.
6. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation and, at season's end, analyzes staff
effectiveness and evaluates all assistants.
7. Maintains discipline, adjusts grievances and works to increase morale and cooperation.
8. Performs such other duties which may be assigned by the athletic director/principal.
ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES:
9. Assists the athletic director in scheduling, providing transportation and requirements for tournament
and special sport events.
10. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to
scheduled facility times. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees.
11. Provides documentation to fulfill state and system requirements concerning physical examinations,
parental consent and eligibility.
12. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites.
13. Advises the athletic director and recommends policy, method or procedural changes.
STUDENT RESPONSIBILITIES:
14. Serves as a mentor to each athlete to promote the development and demonstration in student athletes
the character traits of trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship.
15. Gives constant attention to a student athlete's grades and conduct.
16. By his/her presence at all practices games and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance and
safeguards for each participant.
17. Provides training rules and any other unique regulations of the sport to each athlete who is
considered a participant.

Job.JobTitle: DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School
Job.JobDescription:
The DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School position at Monta Vista High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Monta Vista High School, the DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the DANCE TEAM ADVISOR - Monta Vista High School at Monta Vista High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
