Job Specifications: In order to be successful in this job, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skills and/or abilities required. Reasonable accommodation may be made to enable individuals with disabilities, who are otherwise qualified, to perform the essential functions. Essential Responsibilities: * Manage and supervise athletic activities, contests, and practice sessions, to promote individual growth in athletic skills, teamwork, discipline, respect, and good sportsmanship. * Prepare field/courts on Game Day and manage logistics for all lower level competitions * Check and respond to Centinela Outlook email on a regular basis * Use a variety of instructional techniques and media to meet the needs and improve the abilities of student-athletes. * Coordinate the development and promotion of the specific Program. * Work with other members of school staff to plan and put in place instructional goals and objectives to ensure the overall educational development of student athletes. * Ensure all coaches work together toward a common goal within the program and provide unity within all levels of the program. * Establish performance criteria for competition and evaluate students’ athletic abilities initially and on a regular basis. * Develop a regular practice schedule and organize practice time to provide both individual and team development. * Hold a preseason meeting with all student-athletes and parents before the first official game. * Assess players’ skills and assign team positions. * Determine game strategy based on the team’s capabilities. * Monitor and enforce student eligibility criteria for extracurricular participation. * Apply and enforce student discipline during athletic contests, practice sessions, and while on trips off school property. * Encourage sportsmanlike conduct in all phases of athletic participation at all times (coaches and athletes) * Take all necessary precautions to protect student-athletes, equipment, and facilities, including protecting students from hazing/bullying. * Maintain and secure all equipment and uniforms. * Oversee the process of cleaning, repairing, and storing all athletic equipment. * Communicating with the Athletic Director to ensure compliance with all pertinent CIF regulations, including eligibility forms, transfer forms, and grade reports. * Instruct and advise students on NCAA regulations with regard to academic requirements for scholarships and recruiting practices. * Assist student athletes with college recruitment. * Assist the Athletic Director with the scheduling of games and coordinate arrangements. * Act as a team representative and promote the sport by communicating with the news media, and other organizations. * Participate in special activities to include senior night, banquets, award nights and pep assemblies. * Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding athletic performance of their student. * Coordinate with the ATC and established procedures in the event of an athlete’s injury. * Represent the Centinela Valley Union High School District and program in a professional manner. * Maintain nondiscriminatory practices in all activities. * Attend staff development meetings, clinics, and other professional activities to improve coaching performance. * Perform any other related duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or other appropriate administrator. * Recommend, advocate, and attend all league, all area, and other award nominations. Additional Knowledge/Skills/Attributes/Certificates: Knowledge: * Comprehensive knowledge of the game is paramount. Extensive knowledge of current coaching techniques and procedures. * Knowledge of NFHS and CIF rules and regulations. * Demonstrated ability to instruct and supervise student-athletes. Skills: * The applicant must possess the ability to communicate in spoken and written word. * Excellent organizational, communication, and interpersonal skills. * The applicant must possess the ability to relate to students and to teach them on and off the field. * The applicant must be willing to accept a high level of accountability. * The applicant must possess the ability to assess players and coaches effectively. Attributes: * The applicant should be professionally calm and motivationally intense. * The applicant should be a progressive thinker but a believer in planning and preparation. Certificates: * NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching or Sport Specific * NFHS Concussion in Sports (every 2 years) * NFHS Sudden Cardiac Arrest (every 2 years) * NFHS Heat Illness Prevention (every 2 years) * Valid CPR/First-Aid card Supervision Exercised: Assistant Coaches, Staff Supervision Received: Principal /Athletic Director

Job.JobDescription: Job Summary The La Cañada High School Athletics Department has an opening for the Boys Varsity Head Water Polo Coach. The team practices the full year and has its competitive season in the fall, approximately August through October. Outside parties may submit an electronic application through the posting on EdJoin (www.edjoin.org/lcusd). An introduction letter and/or coaching portfolio are welcome but not required. Experience: Two years or more of successful experience coaching high school, collegiate or elite/club water polo. 2. Licenses: Current first aid and CPR certifications. Work Calendar: The competitive season ranges approximately August through October. The varsity head coach may be asked to work with the team year-round, including summers, for practice and strength training. The chosen candidate will assume coaching responsibilities as soon as clearance is confirmed from a background check, tuberculosis skin test reading and completion of the onboarding process. Compensation: The stipend for this position is $4,010.00 annually, paid as a lump sum at the conclusion of the competitive season. Additional compensation is paid at a daily rate for the length of time the team participates in CIF finals. The daily rate for CIF compensation is calculated by dividing the regular stipend by the number of days in the regular season Benefits: This position does not meet the eligibility requirements to participate in the District's health and welfare benefits.

Job.JobDescription:
The HEAD GIRLS' SOCCER COACH - SKY VIEW role at SKY VIEW HIGH SCHOOL is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the HEAD GIRLS' SOCCER COACH - SKY VIEW is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At SKY VIEW HIGH SCHOOL, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The HEAD GIRLS' SOCCER COACH - SKY VIEW sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At SKY VIEW HIGH SCHOOL, the HEAD GIRLS' SOCCER COACH - SKY VIEW is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the HEAD GIRLS' SOCCER COACH - SKY VIEW at SKY VIEW HIGH SCHOOL is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Coach - Assistant Cheer - South role at Dan Schreier emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Coach - Assistant Cheer - South coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. Athlete support is ongoing. The Coach - Assistant Cheer - South monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Coach - Assistant Cheer - South must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Dan Schreier.

The Strength and Conditioning Coach meets regularly with sport coaches to determine what the athletes need to work on. If working with an injured athlete engaged in rehabilitation, the Strength and Conditioning Coach will consult with the sports medicine or licensed athletic training staff. The Strength and Conditioning Coach is responsible for maintaining the strength and conditioning facility, and for establishing policies, plans, and procedures for the safe and professional operation of the facility.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities
1. Design and implement strength training and conditioning programs in-season, off-season, and pre-season for all school-sanctioned male and female athletic programs in a manner that reflects research-driven practices. 2. Work in cooperation with the sports medicine or athletic training staff in the rehabilitation and strengthening of injured athletes. 3. Facilitate a collaborative relationship among sport coaches, sports medicine, and the strength and conditioning staff. 4. Design and implement policies and procedures for the strength and conditioning program in accordance with the NSCA Strength and Conditioning Professional Standards and Guidelines. 5. Develop systems for tracking athlete attendance and athlete progress in conjunction with the sport coaches. 6. Conduct an annual needs-analysis for each sport team in conjunction with the sport coach and the team’s athletic trainer at the conclusion of each sport season. 7. Annually conduct and review a departmental risk management plan. 8. Complete an annual budgetary proposal for the program that includes routine maintenance, purchase of new equipment, and staffing needs. 9. Determine and reinforce expectations for athlete conduct that mirror the school’s expectations for curricula and extra-curricular activities, as stated in the school’s Student Code of Conduct.
Peripheral Duties and Responsibilities
1. Design and assist curricular strength and conditioning classes, as needed. 2. Other duties as assigned. 3. Adhere to hourly allocations dedicated to strength and conditioning responsibilities.
Qualifications
1. A current relevant professional certification credentialed by an independent accreditation agency—for example, the NSCA Certified Strength and Conditioning Specialist® (CSCS®) certification. 2. Current standard first aid, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and automated external defibrillation (AED) certifications. 3. A strong working knowledge and teaching skills in analysis and techniques of strength training. 4. Experience and/or expertise in strength and conditioning programming for high school populations. 5. Strong motivational abilities. 6. Evidence of ability to interact positively with student athletes, colleagues, and the public. 7. Evidence of strong organizational skills and effective oral and written communication skills.
Physical Requirements
Ability to demonstrate the appropriate skills and techniques to be used by the athletes. Ability to visually monitor athletes. Sitting, standing, lifting and carrying (up to 50 pounds), reaching, squatting, climbing stairs, kneeling, and moving equipment/boxes up to 50 lbs.
Safety and Health Requirements
1. Current standard first aid, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and automated external defibrillation (AED) certifications. 2. Knowledge of universal hygiene precautions. 3. Knowledge of current NSCA Strength and Conditioning Professional Standards and Guidelines.
Equipment/Materials Handled
Must know how to operate strength training equipment, automated external defibrillator (AED), and sports aid equipment.
Work Environment
Must be able to work within various degrees of noise, temperature, and air quality. Work surfaces will vary from concrete to grass to hardwood floors. Job responsibilities require both inside and outside assignments. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignments without direct supervision. Evening and weekend work will be expected. Must be able to work under stressful conditions.

Job.JobTitle: Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade (2025/2026)
Job.JobDescription:
The Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade at Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D. is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D., coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D. operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D. with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade role at Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D..

Job.JobTitle: JV Boys' Volleyball Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The JV Boys' Volleyball Coach position at Chris Borasi provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the JV Boys' Volleyball Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Chris Borasi, the JV Boys' Volleyball Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The JV Boys' Volleyball Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the JV Boys' Volleyball Coach at Chris Borasi is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Paraprofessional Coach - Girls' Water Polo Head Coach position at Brian Shapiro is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Paraprofessional Coach - Girls' Water Polo Head Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Brian Shapiro, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Paraprofessional Coach - Girls' Water Polo Head Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Paraprofessional Coach - Girls' Water Polo Head Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Paraprofessional Coach - Girls' Water Polo Head Coach role at Brian Shapiro is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Primary Purpose: The Middle School Athletic Trainer provides athletic healthcare services for student-athletes across three middle school campuses. Primary assignments will be at the middle school level, but responsibilities are not exclusive to these campuses. The athletic trainer will receive support and collaboration from the high school athletic training staff.
This position is responsible for injury prevention, evaluation, treatment, and rehabilitation; communication with coaches, parents, and healthcare providers; and ensuring compliance with UIL, district, and state guidelines. This role requires independent decision-making, strong organizational skills, and the ability to travel between multiple campuses.
Education/Certification Bachelor's degree in Athletic Training or related field Texas Board of Athletic Trainers License (LAT) or Certification by the Board of Certification (BOC) Current CPR/AED/First Aid certification
Experience Experience working with secondary school athletes Experience managing multiple sites or schedules Knowledge of UIL regulations and Texas school athletic policies
Major Responsibilities and Duties: · Assist in the planning and implementation of a comprehensive athletic injury and illness prevention program for student athletes. · Attend practice sessions and athletic contests as assigned by AD, Assistant AD and Head Athletic Trainer. · Be available for HOME events (7th through Varsity) as assigned. · Establish and maintain effective communication with students, parents, medical and paramedical personnel, coaches, and other staff. · Prepare athletes for games and practices by conducting evaluations and using tape, wraps, splints, braces, & other protective devices as needed. · Respond to emergencies and make quick, independent judgments about how to deal with injuries. · Identify acute injuries and provide first-aid triage, including assessing injuries and deciding whether an athlete should seek further medical attention and should discontinue participation in the athletic event. · Assist the Head Athletic Trainer in establishing specific procedures to be carried out by a coach or student athletic trainer in the event of a medical emergency. · Compile, maintain, and file all physical and computerized reports, records, and other documents including doctor, accident, and treatment records as required. · Maintain an inventory of training supplies and equipment. · Assist with the organization and monitoring of UIL required physical examinations for all athletics 7-12. · Assist the Head Athletic trainers with all Staff Development pertaining to athlete safety in accordance w/ State mandates and UIL Policies. · Communicate utilizing the prescribed chain of command.
Leadership Qualities: · Has the ability to Connect with All by building trust across campus departments and within the community, creating collaborative processes that value varying perspectives, and providing clear and transparent communication. · Seeks opportunities to Invest in Growth by developing self, empowering others, and embracing reflective practices that encourages growth toward goal attainment among staff.
Supervisory Responsibilities: Direct the work of student assistants.

Job.JobTitle: Basketball (Girls) JV Head Coach
Job.JobDescription:
STARTING STIPEND: $2718+ (Based on Experience) Season Runs October through March
SUMMARY: To help each participating student achieve a high level of skill development, and create an appreciation for the values of student connectedness, discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem.
OVERALL DUTIES A. Coaches individual participants in the skills necessary for excellent achievement in the sport involved. B. Plans, schedules, and attends a regular program of practice in season. C. Oversees the safety conditions of the facility or area in which assigned sport is conducted. D. Establishes participant criteria based on student athlete skill, ability, and eligibility and informs parents and participants of these criteria. E. Works collaboratively with the athletic director and varsity head coach in implementing the philosophy and direction of the sport. F. Enforces discipline and sportsmanlike behavior at all times, and establishes and oversees penalties for breach of such standards by individual students. G. Maintains, monitors, and reacts to daily attendance reports and participant/emergency medical cards as necessary. H. Demonstrates knowledge in the areas of physical and emotional health and safety. I. Maintains competency in understanding and enforcing WIAA, Big 8 Conference and School Board rules, policies, and procedures. J. Enforces WIAA and district policies regarding eligibility criteria in interscholastic competition in the sport and monitors it through district software. K. Adheres to a highly efficient and technically sound program of injury prevention and follow up. L. Works closely with the high school athletics and activities director and varsity head coach in interscholastic contests. M. Recommends purchase of equipment, supplies, and uniforms to head varsity coach. N. Responsible for all equipment. O. Develops a consistent and positive public communications procedure through the school and media to inform the parents and the general public about the athletic program. P. Acts as a liaison with the booster clubs. Q. Keeps other coaches informed of rules and other relevant changes within the particular sport. R. Uses generally accepted practices and discretion in determining the proper course of action while using good decision-making skills. Demonstrates emotional maturity. S. Represents the district in professional manner. T. Other duties may be assigned by the athletic department. PRE-SEASON DUTIES 1. Plans, communicates, and executes with cooperation of the head varsity coach a pre-season meeting for prospective student-athletes and their parents to communicate team schedule, policies and procedures. 2. Develops and distributes a team handbook in cooperation with the varsity head coach by the first team meeting to include at least the following: practice schedule, team rules and policies, coaching philosophy statement, special dates and events, game schedule, team tryout process and criteria, lettering policy, how parents/students should communicate with head coach, and how players earn playing time. 3. Attends and participates in Athletic Department sponsored athletic code meetings. 4. Attends annual clinics or workshops that aim to enhance knowledge of the specific sport or other area as assigned by administration. 5. Selects and defines responsibilities of student managers. 6. Determines and communicates responsibilities of assistant coaches. Provides inservices for assistant and sub-varsity coaches via staff meetings, program goals, duties definition and expectations, etc. Recommends assistant or volunteer coaches to the High School Athletics and Activities Director. IN-SEASON DUTIES A. Takes the initiative to communicate activity on a regular basis to the High School Athletics and Activities Director. B. Plans and executes a regular program of practice in season. C. Develops and completes practice plans for each practice session. Provides documentation for each practice session upon request of administration. D. Establishes a team philosophy and system that is complementary and/or supportive to that of the entire program. E. Maintains accurate statistics, records, and results of the season. POST-SEASON DUTIES A. Collects, inventories, and arranges to clean and repair all equipment. Provides inventory documentation upon request of administration. SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITIES: Supervises students of particular program.
QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS: To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
EDUCATION and/or EXPERIENCE: Coaching in the particular sport, with at least 3 years of experience. Experience at the middle/high school level preferred. First aid, CPR, and Blood Borne Pathogen training is required. Knowledge in sports medicine would be desirable.
COMMUNICATION AND LANGUAGE SKILLS: Ability to read and interpret documents such as safety rules, operating and maintenance instructions, and procedure manuals. Ability to write routine reports and correspondence. Ability to speak effectively before groups of students, parents or employees of the district.
MATHEMATICAL SKILLS: Ability to calculate figures and amounts such as discounts, interest, commissions, proportions, percentages, area, circumference, and volume. Ability to apply concepts of basic algebra and geometry.
OTHER SKILLS AND ABILITIES: Exhibit qualities of leadership and organizational ability and reflect a spirit of cooperation in working with staff and school administration. Ability to apply knowledge of current research and theory in a specific field. Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with students, staff and the community. Ability to communicate clearly and concisely both in verbal and written form. Ability to perform duties with awareness of all district requirements, WIAA requirements, and School Board policies. Ability to use computers and other technology to accomplish job responsibilities.
ANALYTICAL AND REASONING ABILITY: Ability to apply common sense understanding to carry out instructions furnished in written, oral, or diagram form. Ability to deal with problems involving several concrete variables in standardized situations.
TEMPERAMENTS: Ability to connect, inspire, and lead students with a variety of learning styles and diverse backgrounds. Ability to direct others, deal with people and influence people in their opinions, attitudes, and judgments. Ability to work effectively with people who express conflicting opinions. Ability to maintain poise, develop a pattern of consistency when dealing with stressful situations, and put the best interest of the students as a whole above all else. Ability to make judgments and decisions by solving problems, making evaluations, or reaching conclusions. Ability to perform a variety of duties.

Job.JobTitle: Head Cheer Coach [C108]
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Cheer Coach [C108] role at JOHNSON JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Head Cheer Coach [C108] is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At JOHNSON JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Head Cheer Coach [C108] sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At JOHNSON JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL, the Head Cheer Coach [C108] is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Head Cheer Coach [C108] at JOHNSON JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: INTERIM MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH (ASSISTANT TRACK)
Job.JobDescription:
The INTERIM MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH (ASSISTANT TRACK) position at RIVERTON MIDDLE SCHOOL is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The INTERIM MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH (ASSISTANT TRACK) is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At RIVERTON MIDDLE SCHOOL, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The INTERIM MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH (ASSISTANT TRACK) encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The INTERIM MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH (ASSISTANT TRACK) also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the INTERIM MIDDLE SCHOOL COACH (ASSISTANT TRACK) role at RIVERTON MIDDLE SCHOOL is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription:
Fremont County School District Number 25 POSITION TITLE: HIGH SCHOOL ASSISTANT COACH (VOLLEYBALL) REPORTS TO: HEAD COACH/ACTIVITIES DIRECTOR DEPARTMENT: ACTIVITIES
POSITION SUMMARY: The Assistant Coach works under the direction of the Head Coach. They should be a creative motivator, have effective communication skills, and possess a positive coaching style. This person must also set appropriate level expectations for their sports team while maintaining strong, healthy relationships with students, parents, teachers, and administrators.
PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITIES * Foster the department, school philosophy and mission statement of Fremont County Schools. * Establish philosophy and system to teach fundamental skills and techniques to their staff and student-athletes. * Interest in fostering diversity, inclusion, and social justice to promote a healthy learning environment. * Keep everyone informed and implement league bylaws, rules, and regulations, as well as those of the school’s handbook and National Federation Rules Book. * See that lower-level head coaches, assistant coaches, and student-athletes adhere to an established Code of Ethics. * Coordinate contest transportation and early departure time and/or other special arrangements as discussed with and approved by the Activities Director. * Assist in the care and upkeep of facilities and equipment. * Maintain a team web page (rosters, results, etc.). * Delegate supervision assignments to their coaching staff, including locker room, practice area, buses, locker room, away games, weight room, etc., to maintain safety. * Attend appropriate meetings for the league, coaching staff, and Activities Department. * Help represent the department at various events, including admission open houses, general parent meetings, banquets, etc. * Other duties as assigned.
TECHNICAL COMPETENCIES AND SKILLS * Possesses strong oral and written communication skills * Works independently with little direct supervision * Works as part of a team * Accepts responsibility and is self-motivated * Demonstrates strong work ethic to achieve District goals * Displays effective multitasking and time management skills
LANGUAGE SKILLS Ability to read and interpret documents such as policies and regulations, safety rules, operating and maintenance instructions, and procedure manuals. Ability to write routine correspondence.
PHYSICAL DEMANDS The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. The employee frequently is required to talk or hear. The employee is occasionally required to stand and reach with hands and arms. The employee must frequently lift and/or move up to 10 pounds and occasionally lift and/or move up to 25 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and ability to adjust focus.
EVALUATION Performance on this job will be evaluated in accordance with school board policy and administrative regulations on evaluation of certified or classified personnel.
SALARY SCHEDULE This position will be paid according to the approved Coach Contracts Salary Schedule.
TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT Sport Calendar, unless otherwise assigned by supervisor.

Job.JobTitle: Monache High School Assistant Varsity Swimming/Diving Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Monache High School Assistant Varsity Swimming/Diving Coach at Justin St Clair is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Monache High School Assistant Varsity Swimming/Diving Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Justin St Clair use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Monache High School Assistant Varsity Swimming/Diving Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Monache High School Assistant Varsity Swimming/Diving Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Monache High School Assistant Varsity Swimming/Diving Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Justin St Clair. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach -Offensive Coordinator Coach, Wide Receivers Coach, and Defensive Back Coach at Jaime Anderson is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Athletic Coach -Offensive Coordinator Coach, Wide Receivers Coach, and Defensive Back Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Jaime Anderson reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Athletic Coach -Offensive Coordinator Coach, Wide Receivers Coach, and Defensive Back Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Athletic Coach -Offensive Coordinator Coach, Wide Receivers Coach, and Defensive Back Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Athletic Coach -Offensive Coordinator Coach, Wide Receivers Coach, and Defensive Back Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Jaime Anderson. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription:
The HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD role at Kelly Landendorf Boden is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Kelly Landendorf Boden are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Kelly Landendorf Boden, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the HEAD VARSITY FOOTBALL COACH - EHS - EUHSD at Kelly Landendorf Boden, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Track and Field Position role at Michelle Noeth emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Track and Field Position coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Michelle Noeth, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Track and Field Position reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Michelle Noeth at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Track and Field Position may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Track and Field Position monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Track and Field Position must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Michelle Noeth.

Job.JobTitle: Strength & Conditioning Coordinator
Job.JobDescription:
Primary Purpose:
To work cooperatively with the coaches and serve as a consultant to them on improving the performance of their athletes in the athletic arena while aiding in the prevention of injuries. Once training program has been decided cooperatively, Strength and Conditioning Coach is responsible for implementation and organization.
Qualifications:
Bachelor’s degree Teacher Certification Preferred Certified Strength & Conditioning Specialist or similar applicable certification preferred Prior Strength & Conditioning coach experience at high school or collegiate level CPR/AED/First Aid CDL or will attain in the next year Familiarity with UIL rules and regulations Strong communication and interpersonal skills
Major Responsibilities and Duties:
Instructional Management
To promote improvement and provide effective instruction, the strength and conditioning coach:
Designs and supervises weight training and conditioning programs for all boys’ and girls’ sports in Temple ISD for pre-season, in-season, and off-season. This includes setting up and taking down of all strength and conditioning equipment used daily. Works in cooperation with the middle school coaches to design and implement an effective strength and conditioning fundamental training model. Works in cooperation with athletic trainers in minimizing and rehabilitating injuries as well as the strengthening of injured athletes. Is responsible for the daily operation of the strength and conditioning facility as well as the coordination and scheduling of the facility before, after the school day, and throughout the year. Prepares well-organized, written strength & conditioning plans which utilize the coaching staff and team to its maximum potential. Plans, organizes, and directs summer strength & conditioning camps for both high school and middle school athletes. Communicates expected student behavior related to athletics and ensures student compliance.
Organization Climate
To foster a positive school or organization morale, the strength and conditioning coach:
Maintains a clean, safe, and efficient weight facility. Maintains a positive working relationship with the TISD coaching staff.
Organization Improvement
To improve each school and sports program, the strength & conditioning coach:
Establishes and monitors all rules and regulations that are to be followed by all users of TISD strength and conditioning facilities. Provides supervision and ensures the safety and security of athletes by closely monitoring conduct of athletes while using TISD strength and conditioning facilities.
Communication and Community Relations
To develop and promote positive communication and relations, the strength and conditioning coach:
Keeps the Athletic Director informed of events within the strength and conditioning programs. Promotes a positive environment and image for the athletic program through effective interpersonal relationships with administration, faculty, parents, teachers, and community leaders. Demonstrates the use of appropriate and effective techniques to encourage community and parental support.
Personnel Relations/Management
To effectively manage student-athlete and program personnel, the strength and conditioning coach will:
Be responsible for planning, organizing, and conducting annual coaches training regarding strength & conditioning program so that all participants may work cooperatively and effectively to implement the TISD strength and conditioning program. Be responsible for a coordinated strength and conditioning program in cooperation with the director of athletics, athletics coaches, and sports medicine staff. Be responsible for monitoring effective working relationships with the middle school coaches in the overall strength and conditioning program.
Organization Management
To effectively manage functions related to administration, facilities, and fiscal responsibilities, the strength and conditioning coach:
Creates, distributes, and maintains detailed, accurate and updated records for each high school athlete to track progress, develop work out schedules and assess effectiveness of programs. Provides a longitudinal report to each coach following the administration of physical testing.
Professional Growth and Development
To engage in professional growth and development, the strength & conditioning coach:
Attends professional workshops to keep abreast of new techniques in strength and conditioning and athletic training.
Qualities of Effective Strength & Conditioning Coach
Demonstrates a high degree of ethical behavior Complies with all district and campus routines and regulations Maintains a professional appearance and demeanor

Job.JobTitle: ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS
Job.JobDescription:
The ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS position at Emerald Ridge High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS at Emerald Ridge High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Emerald Ridge High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the ASSISTANT COACH - GIRLS TENNIS position at Emerald Ridge High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Assistant Coach - Baseball at Greenacres Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Assistant Coach - Baseball is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Greenacres Middle School, the Assistant Coach - Baseball helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Assistant Coach - Baseball may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Greenacres Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Assistant Coach - Baseball follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Assistant Softball - North position at Waukesha North High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Coach - Assistant Softball - North prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Girls Tennis Coach role at Mike Pernsteiner emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The Head Boys Soccer at Williamstown Middle/High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. Culture is a central focus of this job. At Williamstown Middle/High School, the Head Middle 7/8th Girls Track helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Head Middle 7/8th Girls Track may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Williamstown Middle/High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Head Middle 7/8th Girls Track follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Track Coach
Job.JobDescription:
RESPONSIBILITIES: The head coach is responsible for the following: 1. Leadership and support in area of responsibility. 2. Establishing and implementing an improvement process for area of responsibility. 3. Establishing good public and employee relations in area of responsibility. 4. Maintaining professional work habits. 5. Maintaining and upgrading his/her professional skills. 6. Evaluating personnel under his/her supervision.
PERFORMANCE STANDARDS: The following performance standards related to the responsibilities listed below: 1. Leadership and support in area of responsibility. Be responsible for implementing the entire program and overall supervision of his/her program, including J.V. and 9tb Grade Complex teams. Direct assignments and duties of assistant coaches working in his/her- sport. Be responsible for keeping practice periods for his/her sport within realistic or predetermined time allotments. Be responsible for the general maintenance and protection of equipment under his/her jurisdiction. Maintain regular contact and communication with the athletic director any information regarding program. Be responsible for a complete inventory, at the end of each season, of the equipment used for his/her sport. Be responsible for keeping records as requested by the athletic director. Be responsible for submitting a requisition of uniforms and equipment for his/her sport. Be responsible for securing all facilities used upon completion of each practice. Be responsible for the preparation of facilities for games and contests. Obtain all athlete physical exam reports subsequent to the start of his/her season. Review the grade point average on each athlete in his/her program each six weeks. Any student below a 2.0 average shall be referred to the athletic director. Be responsible for the actions and conduct of his/her team whenever they are under his/her jurisdiction. Emphasize safety precautions to control injury. Inform his/her team of all school and athletic rules and regulations, with specific emphasis on the Athletic Code of Conduct, and other athletic department policies. Carry out assigned functions or activities designated by the principal or athletic director. Assist students who wish to further their education and participate in sports. 2. Establishing and implementing an improvement process for area of responsibility: Complete, at the end of his/her season, a self-evaluation report evaluating his/her program and making recommendations for improvements. Implement a good sportsmanship program. Establish a process, for self and assistants, for knowing the rules in the WVSSAC Handbook and at all times abide by them. Implement a general health and welfare program for students in his/her sport and give appropriate attention to athletes who are injured or ill or otherwise incapacitated. All students will be treated fairly and equitably. Establish guidelines for members of his/her team regarding appropriate dress for trips to other schools. Maintain a safe playing area, showers and locker rooms for student participation. Apply discipline in a firm and positive manner. 3. Establishing good public and employee relations in area of responsibility: Develop a sound relationship with the school and community. Communicate with the principal concerning departure time for trips that involve loss of school time, and for seeing that the faculty is given adequate and appropriate notice. Implement a home transportation plan for all participants when returning from road trips in late evening hours. Post practice schedules for convenience of athletes and parents. Clarify athlete award policies with athletes. Maintain positive relationship with media and promptly report scores. 4. Maintaining professional work habits: Be punctual for athletic contests and practice sessions. Demonstrate professional attitude by responding to suggestions and constructive criticism in a positive manner. Work cooperatively with administration and school staff. Maintain a professional appearance. Conduct self and teams in an ethical manner during contests and practice. 5. Maintaining and upgrading his/her professional skills: Accept and use new rules and regulations regarding his/her sport. Attend the WVSSAC rules clinic. Maintain and upgrade professional skills by involvement in the following: staff development (clinics, etc.), reading professional articles, advanced degrees, research and professional associations. 6. Evaluating personnel under his/her supervision: Observe, document and assist the Athletic Director in evaluating assistant coaches. Provide recommendations and suggestions for improving coaching instruction.
If a coach is to be away from his/her classes for athletic events, it is his/her responsibility to see that the class is covered by a teacher and that a desirable learning situation exists. The principal shall approve the covering teacher and the planned class activity. If a coach is unable to find teachers to cover his/her classes during his/her absence, he/she then is not to leave for that sporting event. Each head coach shall submit an itemized inventory and a requisition list by the dates set forth by the athletic director. There shall be no hazing or initiation practices conducted on athletes or athletic teams. The head coach of each sport is responsible for the entire program of that sport.
ADDITIONAL JOB INFORMATION: A successful work history and a minimum of three supervisory references required for consideration. Jefferson County Schools is bound by statute to recommend the most qualified applicants for position vacancies. In order to determine those qualifications as set forth by the West Virginia Code, we require all applicants to fill out an application, which includes supervisory references, and, in many instances, participate in interviews. Failure to provide references, negative references, and failing to participate in requested interviews may impact negatively a candidate's qualifications. Applicants who have been dismissed or have had their contracts non-renewed for cause are not eligible for consideration. Applicants who receive unfavorable reference recommendations will not be eligible for consideration. Applicants must complete the entire application and provide all documents required. Failure to complete the application, provide requested items, or falsification of information will result in the application not being considered. The information contained in the job description is for compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and is not an exhaustive list of duties performed by this position. Additional duties are performed by the individuals currently holding this position and additional duties may be assigned by the Superintendent or his/her designee.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Outdoor Track Coach [C094]
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Outdoor Track Coach [C094] position at CENTRAL HIGH SCHOOL is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Outdoor Track Coach [C094] is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At CENTRAL HIGH SCHOOL, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Outdoor Track Coach [C094] encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Outdoor Track Coach [C094] also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Outdoor Track Coach [C094] role at CENTRAL HIGH SCHOOL is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
